passages.text: EUROPE | European Midcaps

This week, we took a fresh look at investment ideas for the current market phase, changing 6 ratings and highlighting 15 top picks across 5 themes: Oversold cyclicals (AALB, FPE, BFSA) Mispriced structural winners (ARCAD, BEIJ, IMDC, TPE) Consumer recovery (DOC, INPST, SIX2, THULE) German stimulus plays (BC8, COK) Powering the future Data centers & AI (BEAN, MTRS). Further, we initiated on KRN (Buy, PT €175) the leader in packaging & bottling technology.

Exploring Opportunities in European Mid- Caps (2025- 08- 27). Whilst tariffs have held back a broader SMID revival, we already witnessed signs of a trend reversal, following the longest underperformance on record. The anticipation of the German stimulus and a potential ceasefire provides a positive set- up for Europe and re- rating potential for growth- related sectors and cyclical names. In this note we take a fresh look at investment ideas for the current market phase, we change 6 ratings and highlight 15 top picks (Link)

Krones (KRN- DE, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €4.2B) - The Next Frontier in Filling & Packaging Solutions; Initiate at Buy (2025- 08- 26). A global leader in packaging and bottling technology, Krones operates at the intersection of structural beverage growth, sustainability- driven investment, and automation. With clear strategy, strong execution, and a robust financial profile, we believe it is well positioned to grow ahead of the market. On 9x EV/EBIT '26, we anticipate a rerating underpinned by solid earnings growth and new product launches at the CMD in September. Initiate at Buy, €175 PT (Link)

Nordex (NDX1- DE, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €5.1B) - First View: Luxcara Considering Replacing Ming Yang with SGRE Turbines (2025- 08- 25). German asset manager Luxcara said its now considering the use of Siemens Gamesa turbines for its 300MW offshore Waterkant project in the German North Sea, potentially scrapping a deal with Ming Yang Smart Energy, chosen as a preferred turbine supplier in July 2024. The deal had drawn political scrutiny and while Luxcara didn't confirm if political or regulatory scrutiny had played a role in the decision, it did say that their 'primary goal is to successfully implement the energy transition...including by investing in financially sound projects and reliably implementing them with low risk in collaboration with our partners'. We see this as a further evidence that a Chigge entry into the European wind market remains challenging. We are attending WindHusum in September, where we'll meet Chinese manufacturers to provide further color on their development in Europe (Link)

Dermapharm (DMPDE, HOLD, Mkt. Cap: €1.8B) - First View: Prelims And Guidance Confirmed Implying 2H Earnings Step- up (2025- 08- 26). DMP just confirmed 2Q25 preflims and FY25 guidance. 2Q group sales fell by - 3% with robust growth in BP (+6%) and OHP (+4%) not covering the shortfall from strategy induced lower PI sales (- 30%). Adj. EBITDA grew to €66.7m (+4%), translating into a margin of 24.5% (vs. 23.0% in PY), primarily driven by BP where Intl. and allergology areas continue to drive bottom- line growth at a margin of 42.4% (vs. 40.9%). In OHP there is no turnaround achieved with adj. EBITDA down - 14% to €8.6m (- 27% vs. cons.) with a margin just reaching LDD of 10.3% (PY 12.4%). OpCF rose to €65.9 (PY €22.9m) and the FCF improved to €55.9m (PY €14.1m) due to lower working capital demand. Mgmt confirmed the guidance for FY25 which implies flat revenue growth in 2H but an adj. EBITDA acceleration towards +10% to reach the respective mid- points (margin 29.6% vs. 25.8% in 1H25) (Link)

Bunzl (BNZL- GB, UNDERPERFORM, Mkt. Cap: 9.0B) - Interim Results In Line; FY25 Guidance Reiterated (2025- 08- 26). Headline numbers including £404.5m EBITA and 77.5p interim EPS are in line with consensus (£405.3m/77.3p respectively). Day- adjusted organic revenue growth suggests a slight improvement in Q2; though we note very soft comps. FCF and adj ND/EBITDA also came in broadly in line with expectations, and FY25 guidance is reiterated. We note muted M&A activity YTD, and Bunzl resume the remaining £86m of the previously paused £200m 2025 buyback to be completed in H2. (Link)

Cadeler (CADLR- NO, BUY, Mkt. Cap: 1.6B) - CADLR Off the Call - More challenging 2027/28 vs Steady Growth in O&M (2025- 08- 26). The 1H presentation shows CADLR's 3 US contracts: Revolution Wind (2025), Sunrise Wind (2026) & an O&M contract (2025) accounting for \(8\%\) of total £2.5bn backlog. On Revolution & Sunrise, CEO Mikkel Gleerup spoke to the contracts having a "lot of protection" and in response to a question on Scylla - "if the vessel comes free, which I don't believe or hope today, I would like to make that clear, then I think that it could be repurposed to another project" (Link)

Cadeler (CADLR- NO, BUY, Mkt. Cap: 1.6B) - First View: 2Q EBITDA Beats, Recently Upgraded Guidance Reaffirmed (2025- 08- 26). +ve. 2Q EBITDA & net profit is ahead of JEFE and materially ahead of consensus, which is yet to fully reflect the guidance upgrade on 1 July following a termination fee from Orsted. That recently upgraded guidance is reaffirmed in today's results, with 1H EBITDA equating to \(53\%\) of FY25 guidance midpoint. Vessel utilisation improved to \(76\%\) in 2Q, in line with JEFE and up from \(55\%\) in 1Q with seven vessels active in the quarter. Commentary confirms that the remaining four newbuilds under construction are "fully on track". Backlog of £2.5bn as of today is flat since last provided in May with \(97\%\) post- FID. Net debt misses JEFE & consensus however, with higher capex in the quarter, which we expect largely relates to the acquisition of Wind Keeper O&M vessel. Call & presentation at 8am EST / 2pm CET / 1pm UK likely gives commentary on any potential impact from Revolution Wind. (Link)

Cadeler (CADLR- NO, BUY, Mkt. Cap: 1.6B) - First View: Revolution Wind in the US Halted (2025- 08- 25). In another setback for US offshore wind, the US Department of Interior issued a stop- work order on Orsted's under- construction US Offshore Wind project Revolution Wind on 22 August. This is the second major US offshore wind project to be halted; a similar stop- work order was issued on Empire Wind in April, which was lifted a month later, allowing construction to resume. In our Energy Services coverage, CADLR and SUBC have (low) exposure to Revolution Wind. (Link)

Nordex (NDX1- DE, BUY, Mkt. Cap: 5.1B) - First View: Luxcara Considering Replacing Ming Yang with SGRE Turbines (2025- 08- 25). German asset manager Luxcara said its now considering the use of Siemens Gamesa turbines for its 300MW offshore Waterkant project in the German North Sea, potentially scrapping a deal with Ming Yang Smart Energy, chosen as a preferred turbine supplier in July 2024. The deal had drawn political scrutiny and while Luxcara didn't confirm if political or regulatory scrutiny had played a role in the decision, it did say that their "primary goal is to successfully implement the energy transition...including by investing in financially sound projects and reliably implementing them with low risk in collaboration with our partners". We see this as a further evidence that a Chinese entry into the European wind market remains challenging. We are attending WindHusum in September, where we'll meet Chinese manufacturers to provide further color on their development in Europe. (Link)

DEME Group NV (DEME- BE, BUY, Mkt. Cap: 3.5B) - Strong 1H25 Offshore Energy Results Likely to Trigger c.10% Consensus Upgrades (2025- 08- 26). 1H25 revenues increased \(10\%\) to £2,117.1m, \(4\%\) ahead of consensus £2,042.8m, driven by growth of \(27\%\) in Offshore Energy, partly offset by lower revenues of \(4\%\) in Dredging & Infra, and \(19\%\) in Environmental. EBITDA surged \(35\%\) to £464.3m, \(29\%\) ahead of consensus £360.3m, implying a 394bps higher margin at \(21.9\%\) , driven by efficient project planning and strong execution in Offshore Energy. The order book was stable at £7,520.8m, corresponding to \(1.7x\) annualised revenues, after order intake decreased \(27\%\) to £1,437.8m, incl. £530m related to the Havfram acquisition. Free cash usage of £413.8m includes £537m for the Havfram acquisition (out of £900m in total), leading to net debt of £418.5m (0.5x EBITDA), vs. £351.8m in 1H24. For FY25E, DEME confirms guidance for turnover to be at least in line with FY24, based on its order book, but now expects an EBITDA margin to slightly exceed \(20\%\) (vs. at least stable at \(18.6\%\) previously), likely triggering c. \(10\%\) FY25E consensus EBITDA upgrades. (Link)

DEME Group NV (DEME- BE, BUY, Mkt. Cap: 3.5B) - Profitability Reaching New Highs, While Tender Activity Remains Strong (2025- 08- 27). 1H25 results reflected an estimated underlying EBITDA margin improvement of 250bps to c. \(20.5\%\) , vs. cons. \(17.5\%\) , due to efficient project planning and strong execution in Offshore Energy. Tender activity remains strong, particularly in Dredging & Infra, expected to mitigate \(27\%\) weaker order intake. We have increased EBITDA estimates by \(10\% - 16\%\) , but lowered our DCF- based PT to £175 for the Havfram acquisition for £900m, with still a limited order book of £530m. (Link)

Drax (DRX- GB, BUY, Mkt. Cap: 2.8B) - Back In The Spotlight (2025- 08- 28). The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has launched an investigation into the company covering the period Jan 22 to March 24, relating to certain historical statements regarding Drax's biomass sourcing and the

compliance of its 2021, 2022, and 2023 Annual Reports with the Listing Rules and Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules. Our understanding from speaking with Drax is that the investigation is at a very early stage, and as such, limited information is currently available. Talking to the company, the preliminary understanding is that the FCA may explore themes similar to those raised by Ofgem, but with a focus on financial disclosures. Also, we understand that the FCA does not have jurisdiction over CfD or RO schemes. Nonetheless, the investigation puts Drax in the spotlight and may bring additional political scrutiny on the post- 2027 bridging mechanism, where Drax agreed heads of terms with the UK government earlier in the year, but the process is yet to be finalised. (Link)

Hunting (HTG- GB, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €0.6B) - HTG FV Off the call - Softer Subsea margins to Recover (2025- 08- 28). One area of softness in HTG's otherwise in- line results was the step- down in Subsea margins to 13.1% at 1H25 from 22.6% at 1H24. CFO Bruce Ferguson explained the softness as driven by lower volumes and a product mix with fewer high margin products such as stress joints 'we know the order book is there for the stress joints, which will be recognized more in '26'. Contribution from FES acquisition is also expected to support recovery 'once we get back to more normalized product mix, we've got FES contribution on there. We definitely see this as a 20% EBITDA margin product line. And the volumes coming back' (Link)

Hunting (HTG- GB, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €0.6B) - 1H25 In- line & FY25 Guide Reiterated despite Market Uncertainty (2025- 08- 28). In- line. 1H25 results are as pre- guided while net profit misses on one- offs. FY25 EBITDA guide of 452m (as pre- guided) is - 35% y/y but 'large OCTG tenders are likely to be issued across the Middle East in the second half of the year'. Interim dividend +13% y/y as guided & previously announced \(40m buyback starts today. (Link)

boohoo (DEBS- GB, HOLD, Mkt. Cap: €0.2B) - First View: FY25 results (2025- 08- 27). News. boohoo finally released its FY25 results at 2pm yesterday afternoon, with a few notable elements: 1) £41m of EBITDA was in line with consensus, but only after c.200m of exceptions - including £25m of UK stock clearance, and £16m of UK tech/warehouse dual- running/restructuring costs, 2) a significant loss, with pre- exceptional loss before tax of £65m and a free cash outflow of £40m, 3) a sale of PLT is now being actively pursued, and it is classified as discontinued - it contributed over 1/3 of FY24 group revenue, but swung from an EBITDA of £18m to - £2m, 4) the Debenhams business grew GMV by +34% to £650m and EBITDA from £11m to £25m but remains small, in our view, with a sizeable part of divisional overhead covered by the declining non- core boohoo 'labels', and 5) net debt has been reduced to £78m through the equity raise and asset sales, but funding will continue to be expensive given the new £175m 3yr RCF at base + 7.3%. (Link)

Brunello Cucinelli SpA (BC- IT, HOLD, Mkt. Cap: €6.7B) - Tailor- Made (2025- 08- 28). The July sales update (which confirmed BC as the fastest growing group in Q2) had pre- emptied today's strong H1 results (with EBIT up by c.9% as expected). Comments around a Q3 to date in line with H1 trends, and a confirmation of confidence in a slight margin increase for the FY, will be a focus. Whether investors willing to call a broader Q3 luxury turn continue to relatively de- rate the quality end of the universe remains a near- term consideration. (Link)

Rémy Cointreau (RCO- FR, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €2.9B) - First View: Tariff Relief Partly Reinvested Behind Growth (2025- 08- 29). A press release from Remy bringing up the bottom end of guidance represents the second upgrade from the company as tariff uncertainty has eased. If a deal is reached with the US, this should drive further upside (MSD net of reinvestment). Key positives today include (1) Reiteration of guidance MSD on topline (2) Reinvestment of approx half of the tariff windfall behind growth. There is no change to our view that cognac will recover over the med- term and that Remy will see recovery alongside this. Whilst visibility on timing of recovery is still low, tail risks are abating and Remy's cognac business appears to be bottoming. Shares are trading on 1.5x inventory value vs 10- year avg 4x. (Link)

Royal Unibrew (RBREW- DK, UNDERPERFORM, Mkt. Cap: €3.2B) - 1H Results: Underlying Growth Less Favourable (2025- 08- 27). We like the multibeverage model and Royal Unibrew's strong track record of deal making / cost control. However, with F25 organic growth boosted by the acquired BeLux business, we see a risk that group growth starts to drift as the first- time consolidation of these activities is cycled. Whilst RU remains a well- run business, we see cheaper ways to play EU bets, with ABI/HEIA at 2026 EV/EBITDA

see margin headwinds as the next leg of downside. While the stock already de- rated sharply, we continue to see a negative set- up with our estimates well- below consensus and FY26 likely to be another back- end loaded year. (Link)

Chrysalis Investments (CHRY- GB, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €0.7B) - Erratum: Soaring Starling (2025- 08- 26). CHRY's heavy write- up of Starling at the point of the last NAV, and the resulting high degree of portfolio concentration, warrants further analysis of the asset. We find Starling's valuation is high versus traditional lenders, but broadly in- line with other challenger banks, likely reflecting that a strong degree of future revenue and earnings growth is baked into the valuation, particularly now via Engine. (Link)

Gore Street Energy Storage Fund (GSF- GB, HOLD, Mkt. Cap: €0.4B) - A Case for Internalisation? (2025- 08- 27). We see a realistic case for GSF to internalise its management. Such an arrangement would align with and support a number of the goals outlined in the recent strategy review. (Link)

Partners Group Private Equity (PEY- GB, HOLD, Mkt. Cap: €0.7B) - Interims/Q2 Update Call (2025- 08- 28). The high- level portfolio metrics continue to highlight a relatively high valuation multiple versus relatively modest EBITDA growth, albeit some holdings with negative EBITDA growth appear to be dragging on the latter. More positively, the forthcoming completions of the PCI Pharma and Techem disposals are likely to trigger share buybacks under the capital allocation policy. (Link)

Dermapharm (DMP- DE, HOLD, Mkt. Cap: €1.8B) - First View: Prelims And Guidance Confirmed Implying 2H Earnings Step- up (2025- 08- 26). DMP just confirmed 2Q25 prelims and FY25 guidance. 2Q group sales fell by - 3% with robust growth in BP (+6%) and OHP (+4%) not covering the shortfall from strategy induced lower PI sales (- 30%). Adj. EBITDA grew to €66.7m (+4%), translating into a margin of 24.5% (vs. 23.0% in PY), primarily driven by BP where Intl. and allergology areas continue to drive bottom- line growth at a margin of 42.4% (vs. 40.9%). In OHP there is no turnaround achieved yet with adj. EBITDA down - 14% to €8.6m (- 27% vs. cons.) with a margin just reaching LDD of 10.3% (PY 12.4%). OpCF rose to €65.9 (PY €22.9m) and the FCF improved to €55.9m (PY €14.1m) due to lower working capital demand. Mgmt confirmed the guidance for FY25 which implies flat revenue growth in 2H but an adj. EBITDA acceleration towards +10% to reach the respective mid- points (margin 29.6% vs. 25.8% in 1H25). (Link)

Elekta (EKTA B- SE, HOLD, Mkt. Cap: €1.7B) - First Thoughts on 1Q25/26 Results (2025- 08- 28). Slow start to the year as guided with Q1 results broadly in line: OSG 2.5% (cons +1.9%), adj mgn 6.5% (cons 6.1%) and order book down 1%cc (cons - 2%). Vague FY25/26 guide (sales growth; no mgn target) reiterated. No mention of MT guide for mgn returning to 14% and higher. Shares down - 20% YTD, reflecting external pressures (tariffs, hospital budget, FX HWs), a mixed track- record on execution (share losses, EVO's US approval delayed) and a new CEO. (Link)

Elekta (EKTA B- SE, HOLD, Mkt. Cap: €1.7B) - All Hopes On Better H2 Trends (2025- 08- 28). Slow start to the year as guided with Q1 results broadly in line: OSG 2.5% (cons +1.9%), adj mgn 6.5% (cons 6.1%) and order book down 1%cc (cons - 2%). Vague FY25/26 guide (sales growth; no mgn target) reiterated, as is MT guide for mgn returning to 14% and higher. Shares down - 25% YTD, reflecting external pressures (tariffs, hospital budget, FX HWs), a mixed track- record on execution (share losses, EVO's US approval delayed) and a new CEO. (Link)

GN Store Nord (GN- DK, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €2.4B) - Same Story, Same Risks (2025- 08- 26). We leave stacked '25- 27 JEFE EPS roughly unchanged, and raise PT by 12% (mainly on strong execution, peers' re- rating). Rally on Q2 public. is a testimony to the low positioning and expectations of investors. Strong exec. on Q2, and FY25 guide already accommodating for Costco, comp. launches, and a wide range of outcomes in Ent reassure, though macro uncertainties remain. An attractive val., a strong Vivia launch, and potential Ent recovery leave us at Buy. (Link)

IMCD (IMCD- NL, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €5.6B) - First View: Acquisition of Tillmans in Italy Confirms M&A Strategy is on Track (2025- 08- 27). IMCD has signed an agreement to acquire 100% of the shares in Tillmanns S.p.A., a well- established distributor of specialty chemicals in Italy, with revenues of €143m in FY24. This marks IMCD's largest acquisition in terms of revenues since the acquisition of Signet in India in 2020, and increases acquired revenues to €338m ytd, adding 7% to group revenues, amidst recent investor concerns IMCD's M&A strategy was slowing. Tillmanns acts as a key partner for global suppliers, with a broad base of customers, focusing on the coatings, construction, food & nutrition, and water treatment markets. Tillmanns operates a logistics centre in Milan, and an in- house R&D laboratory, offering advanced testing, custom formulations, and technical support.

The acquisition provides a strong strategic fit for IMCD, increasing scale and market presence in Italy, where IMCD realised revenues of €220m in FY23. The acquisition is expected to close in 4Q25E. (Link)

Systemair (SYSR- SE, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €1.8B) - First View: Delivers Mixed 1Q25/26 Results Amid Regional Divergence (2025- 08- 28). Systemair reported mixed 1Q25/26 (May- Jul) results, with net sales of SEK 3,094m (1% above Infront cons), - 0.6% y- o- y, +5.7% organically, and adjusted EBIT of SEK 288m (9% below cons), - 5.6% y- o- y, for a margin of 9.3% (1Q24/25: 9.8%). Regional performance was varied: the Nordic region and Western Europe saw positive growth, while Eastern Europe & CIS declined, and North America was impacted by currency effects despite organic improvement in the US. The Middle East, Asia, Australia, and Africa rebounded strongly, with organic growth of 14.3% as supply disruptions in India were resolved. Gross margin improved to 36.4% due to restructuring and favorable product mix, but operating profit was affected by one- off costs related to a capital loss (SEK 5.7m) and CEO transition (SEK 14.6m). Despite ongoing market uncertainty, management remains optimistic about long- term growth, supported by a diversified footprint, strong balance sheet, and continued investment in energy- efficient solutions. (Link)

Vesuvius (VSVS- GB, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €1.1B) - Updating Forecasts For MMS & 1H25 Interims; Modest FY25F - FY27F Upgrades (2025- 08- 27). Vesuvius' proposed acquisition of the MMS business from Morgan Advanced Materials (Morgan) looked a sensible deal to us (see here for more details), and the use of the Foseco India Ltd listing to help fund the acquisition was innovative. We update our model/forecasts to reflect the proposed MMS acquisition and the recent 1H25 Interims, resulting in +1% FY25F EPS upgrades and +3% EPS upgrades in FY26F & FY27F. Buy reiterated, new PT 500p. (Link)

Flughafen Zurich (FHZN- CH, HOLD, Mkt. Cap: €8.0B) - 1H25: Tracking Higher; Model Updated (2025- 08- 26). FHZN is tracking above expectations in 2025, benefitting from tight cost control and Intl. growth, driving cons. EBITDA 2- 3% higher. On the call, mgmt pointed to charges moderately lower in 2027, under the new charge period. We saw this as a negative, as we had market expectations closer to flat and above VA cons of (- )5%. However, in a volatile market, the near- term upgrade outweighed any disappointment, and we see momentum maintained into H2. Hold. (Link)

Flughafen Zurich (FHZN- CH, HOLD, Mkt. Cap: €8.0B) - 1H25: Solid Print; Guidance Nudged Up (2025- 08- 26). A solid update from FHZN, with H1 EBITDA 2.4% above cons. and guidance up from "approx flat" to "slightly positive" for '25. The beat came from Aviation and Intl., reflecting good cost control and traffic trends, and FY cons. EBITDA likely moves up 1- 2%. Group capex has been trimmed, as FX tailwinds in Intl. are partially offset by higher spend in Zurich. Overall a clean beat, but charges negotiations which start in Oct. remain the key unknown. Call at 10am UK. (Link)

Aroundtown (AT1- DE, UNDERPERFORM, Mkt. Cap: €5.2B) - Soft FFO amid financing drag and lower JV contribution (2025- 08- 27). H1- 25 FFO I is down - 2.4% YoY (€150.4m and €0.14 per share) due to higher coupons on perpetual notes and a - 17% decline in the contribution from JVs. Adjusted EBITDA - 0.3% YoY. LFL rental growth is stable at +3% YoY, with offices remaining subdued (+1.5% vs. +1.6% in Q1). Stable occupancy rate QoQ although - 10bp in Offices. 2025 FFO I guidance confirmed at €0.26- €0.28. Asset values +1.4% LFL. EPRA LTV at 58%; low disposals volume signed YTD. CFO to step down. (Link)

ECP (ECMPA- NL, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €1.5B) - 2025 Guidance to Upper End; CMD on Sept 11, 2025 (2025- 08- 28). While somewhat trailing peers, ECMPA delivered solid H1 figures: LFL rental growth was +3%, rental uplift +2.9%, and vacancy hit a record low of 1.2%. Portfolio value rose by +1.3% in H1, driving NTaps to €41.46 (+5.3% YoY) and EPRA LTV to 43.8% (-1pt YTD). EPS guidance for 2025 now points to the upper end (€2.40- 2.45; JEF est. €2.42). We hope to see ECMPA shifting into investment mode via acquisitions or new projects. CMD is set for Sept 11, 2025. (Link)

Land Securities (LAND- GB, UNDERPERFORM, Mkt. Cap: €4.9B) - PT cut following Debt d/grade on high leveraging in a high rate environment (2025- 08- 27). Guidance for FY30 EPS of 60p looks challenging post the Fitch debt d/grade. Additions to the debt security pool increased property values by only 16% and failed to offset the debt surge to a 42% LTV (LAND since have sold QAM) and a strategic move to invest €1bn in retail, establish a £2bn resi platform, and divest £2bn of offices, carry increasing execution risk in a high- rate environment. Our DCF derived PT is d/graded to 455p, and we maintain an Unpf rec. (Link)

Sagax (SAGA. B- SE, UNDERPERFORM, Mkt. Cap: €6.8B) - First View: Buys 11% stake in Retail Estates (2025- 08- 29). Sagax's acquisition of a 10.8% stake in Retail Estates NV is a surprising strategic move given its core focus on logistics properties, whereas Retail Estates specializes in retail parks/ assets that are more exposed to consumer trends and less aligned with Sagax's traditional investment strategy. This divergence raises questions about Sagax's long- term intentions, particularly the possibility of launching a full takeover bid. However, such a move would be financially tight considering Sagax's current leverage. A share swap deal could be a viable alternative, especially given the NAV premium, but it would likely result in dilution of

David Mindus's stake, which could be a significant deterrent. At an implied yield of c.3.5%, using an equity content would be an interesting lever for Sagax but again without removing question marks on the rationale of this deal. (Link)

Workspace (WKP- GB, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €0.9B) - First View: Wild Doubles Up In Kennington (2025- 08- 26). WKP has signed a new lease with personal care brand Wild Cosmetics following its acquisition by Unilever for £230m as part of a strategy to focus on fewer, bigger innovations and expand its presence in the sustainable personal care market, according to Thelndustry.Beauty. As a result, Wild will move into WKP's current HQ at Kennington Park, The Oval, SW6 with WKP moving its HQ to The Centro Buildings in Camden, NW1 (in Oct 25). (Link)

Delivery Hero (DHER- DE, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €7.1B) - 1H25 Results: First View (2025- 08- 28). Calling how the equity will respond to the H1 results is difficult. The good Q2 / H1 results, with a solid EBITDA beat and improving growth are a clear positive, so too, the language in the release relating to "Positive momentum in Asia, highlighted by a return to growth in APAC and improved growth dynamics in South Korea" (and we look forward to the 1pm UK results call to explore this latter comment). (Link)

Eurowag (WPS- GB, BUY, Mkt. Cap: €0.7B) - H1'25 Preview: Focus on Act. Trucks & Platform Commentary (2025- 08- 26). Eurowag is due to report H1'25 results on 4 Sept (pre- mkt). We expect H1 revenues to grow 9% y/y to €154m, Cash EBITDA of €44m/29%, while active trucks to increase c9% to 112k. The stock rebounded from its low in May and is now up +c13% ytd, despite no major macro recovery in Europe. While we believe sentiment remains cautious with LT catalysts around Mobility unclear, there could be a meaningful shift towards recurring revenue generation - we remain Buyers. (Link)

Softcat (SCT- GB, UNDERPERFORM, Mkt. Cap: €3.6B) - A Year of Adjustments (2025- 08- 28). A FY25 trading statement is slightly ahead, but driven by hard- to- predict large deals. We think this creates complexity, and the potential non- recurrence of such deals puts downward pressure on FY26/7 consensus. Meanwhile, for much of the next 12 months, we will be discussing adjusted growth and adjusted profits. We continue to see better value elsewhere, though we nudge our PT to 1,400p. (Link)

Softcat (SCT- GB, UNDERPERFORM, Mkt. Cap: €3.6B) - FY26 debates (2025- 08- 28). A FY25 statement points to slightly better trading, but once again driven by large deals. This creates complications for FY26. If you back large deals out of forecasts it implies modest downgrades. And if hard to predict deals are the only source of upside that feels unhelpful to a premium valuation multiple. (Link)

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period.
Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12-month period.

The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(is 20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below\) \ \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(, the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus\) 20\% \(or less within a 12- month period.
